awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Bias Modeling and Estimation of Networked Transportation Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will contribute to national prosperity and economic welfare by advancing data analytics applied to transportation systems.  While big data are increasingly used in transportation and other disciplines in science and engineering, the collected data may come with errors and biases, and therefore may not provide an authentic representation of the entire population.  Biased data can lead to ineffectual policies and suboptimal decisions for transportation infrastructure related investment, planning, and operations.  As the transportation field undergoes a major transformation towards smart and autonomous systems, data quality is critical in ensuring that public welfare results from these investments. This award supports a comprehensive investigation and fundamental understanding of the sources, taxonomy, and modeling approaches of data biases and the PIs will develop novel solutions to address the issues. The project team will work closely with transportation practitioners to test and validate the findings of this research, and transfer scientific knowledge to planning and operation practices. The award also supports efforts to broaden STEM interest in engineering and data sciences through updated curricula and virtual seminars, and to provide opportunities for underrepresented communities.

This research will develop theories, models, and algorithms of a novel NETwork-based, Data-Assisted Transportation Analysis (NetData) framework for data bias modeling and estimation, which can recognize and utilize the underlying network structure and processes in the data. The NetData framework will explicitly capture bias and integrate data with proper network models, in both deterministic and stochastic settings and under realistic network considerations such as dynamic and multimodal networks. This research fills an important gap in transportation data sciences and practice in modeling and addressing data bias. The analytical framework leverages and extends state-of-the-art techniques from transportation network science, stochastic optimization, and data science. It will produce algorithms to integrate data from multiple sources to help conduct more accurate and reliable analysis of travel patterns and decisions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Big data and associated data analytics methods (many are based on deep learning or AI techniques) are increasingly used in transportation and other engineering disciplines. Transportation big data however can be inherently biased especially those passively collected from cellular phones, mobile apps, social media, etc. Without properly modeling and addressing biases, data analysis results can be misleading when used for transportation and related decision makings. This research aims to understand big data biases and develop methods to mitigate biases in big data collected on large-size transportation networks.

Major findings of the research:

  • Data bias modeling and mitigation methods: i) A two-stage data generation process can be developed to mimic how transportation big data is generated; ii) The first-stage model captures the social-demographic and device use features about data generation, and the estimation results can reflect data biases in these aspects; iii) The second-stage models the spatial-temporal distribution of the data, for which recommender system methods, widely used in online shopping and digital streaming, may be used to filling missing data and mitigate biases.
  • Large-scale transportation origin-destination (OD) demand estimation: i) The demand matrix of a large-size transportation network has certain quasi-sparse property: most OD pairs hold very small travel demands (e.g., less than two trips per day) and collectively these small demands constitute a relatively small portion of the total demands of the network; ii) Leveraging this quasi-sparsity, a new OD estimation framework, quasi-sparse OD (QSOD) estimation, can be developed; iii) Numerical experiments on a real transportation network show the superb performance of QSOD compared with existing OD estimation methods ; iv) QSOD can be extended to consider stochasticity in data and the transportation system; in particular, a data-driven optimization (DRO) method may be applied to explore such stochasticity.
  • Modeling the mixed flow of connected/automated vehicles (CAV) and human-driven vehicles (HDVs) on a transportation network: i) It is expected to take a long time for CAVs to reach considerable market penetration (e.g., 20% or more), which necessities the investigation of mixed flow of CAVs and HDVs; ii) Traffic flow characteristics (such as headway, flow capacity) depend on the penetration of CAVs; iii) CAVs may be deployed to improve traffic flow and mitigate overall congestion of a network; iv) A dynamic game-theoretic framework is developed to model the mixed flow of CAVs and HDVs.

Major outcomes of the research:

  • Research activities and results: this research produced two (2) journal papers (published or in press; see the detailed list below), three (3) working paper, nine (9) invited seminars, and three (3) conference presentations.
  • Teaching activities: research results are integrated to multiple courses the PI have taught in the last four years, including: Traffic Engineering, Transportation System Analysis, Transportation Networks and Optimization.
  • Graduate student advising: Four (4) Ph.D. students were (partially) supported by this research. One has graduated recently and now works for Google Map. Two (2) of them are scheduled to graduate in the winter and spring of 2023, respectively. One (1) of them is ongoing, and plans to graduate in the fall of 2024.
  • Undergraduate research: Five (5) undergraduate students worked on this research through the REU fund of this project. One (1) of them is a minority or underrepresented student. They were trained for traffic/transit data analysis, Python programming, simulation model development, and presentation of research results.
  • Outreach activities: The team conducted: (i) nine (9) invited talks and three (3) conference presentations; (ii)  multiple meetings with traffic/transportation practitioners on various topics of emerging transportation data and how to use the data to infer useful transportation information, including Washington State Department of Transportation, Puget Sound Regional Council, City of Seattle, Federal Highway Administrations, among others; (iii) dissemination of research results to the industry (e.g., Cuebig, Inrix, Replica) by sharing research results (papers), via face-to-facing meetings, phone calls and emails, and collaborations on research proposals.

Publications (Journal and refereed conference proceedings):

* indicates former or current graduate students

  1. Guo, Q.*, Ban, X., Aziz, H.M.A., 2021. Mixed traffic flow of human driven vehicles and connected/automated vehicles on a dynamic transportation network. Transportation Research Part C 128, 103159. The paper was also presented at the International Symposium on Transportation and Traffic Theory (ISTTT), August, 2022.
  2. Wang, J.*, Lu, S., Liu, H., Ban, X., 2022. Transportation Origin-Destination Demand Estimation with Quasi-Sparsity. Transportation Science, in press (https://doi.org/10.1287/trsc.2022.1178).
  3. Wang, J.*, Zhao, C., Ban, X., 2021. Distributionally Robust Insignificance-based Origin Destination Demand Estimation. Working paper. To be submitted to the 25th International Symposium on Transportation and Traffic Theory (ISTTT).
  4. Angah, O.*, Zhang, Y.*, Naderian, S.*, Keshavarz, S.*, Ban, X., 2022. Macro-Micro traffic prediction via physics-informed deep learning methods. Working paper. To be submitted to Transportation Research Part C.
  5. Zhang, Y.*, Ban, X., 2022. RecSys model to infer missing transportation mobility data. Working paper, To be submitted to Transportation Research Part C.

Last Modified: 11/22/2022
Modified by: Xuegang Ban
